This is good stuff, but worth noting that given a person's diet contains consistent foods (ie, not swapping out or reformulating) and their microbiome is consistent (not changed by introducing variables or new influences), intake of less calories will result in "caloric deficit" and have an effect on body mass.

For anyone wanting to reduce their food intake with that aforementioned concept, I'd recommend two things: appropriate quantity and timed hydration, and being more careful and precise with portion sizes. Drink water first thing in the morning (16oz should be enough for most people), especially before coffee. Drink 8+ ounces water before and after each (major) meal. As a guideline, eat 75% of the portion sizes you normally would for foods with high caloric density (fats and carbohydrates, generally; so consider how beef and chicken are thought of as "protein", look at their total macronutrient profile and notice the fat content), and worry less about low caloric density foods like fibrous low-starch vegetables (without butter or oils), such as broccoli. Have that meal-ending glass of water and wait 20 minutes. If you're actually still hungry at that point, eg: maybe you had a really draining workout, you could consider having that other 25% of the food.

Remember, fat loss is a long game. Weight will fluctuate on a daily basis, but over weeks and months the trend should bear out if you're mostly consistent.

I haven't watched the video yet but my thoughts beforehand is no; it's not a scam! Not a lot of people know this but there's a specific diet called CICO challenge where you basically limit the amount of calories you take in and then burn off more than what you took in (cico = calories in, calories out) !! Normally, the recommended calorie intake you should be using for this diet is 1200 or 1500 and then burn off more than 1200 every day Therefore, it doesn't matter whether you eat 12 eggs for breakfast or chocolate cake for lunch, or even try that new Subway sandwich diet everyone's talking about. As long as you can burn most of it off then go for it! I obviously recommend eating healthy so you don't get diabetes but I'm just saying it's okay to have cheat foods on this diet. Even I eat fruit salads and still crumble those frosted, soft sugar cookies that have sprinkles on the fruit slices and its sooo yummy + I have processed food or chips (both ruffles or veggie chips) as a snack and have STILL lost 26.3lbs in a month. For more proof, I'm working on a weight loss video. Until then you can go to weight loss subreddits on Reddit.com & search up discussions about CICO results. I recommend /r/progresspics & then search up "cico" to see the weight loss results other have made eating whatever they want, just as long as they burned off most of the calories that they took in!

And yes there is still a lot I can and should still learn about health and nutrition. And unfortunately I can't put too much stock into vague facts such as "it takes more energy to break down protein". Because the next thing I should be asking is "how much more are we talking?" Because if difference is very little, then the point looses value. This is just an example to be mindful of vague information.

This is such a confusing and counterproductive way to view calories. Pointing out all the tiny little imperfections inherent to counting calories (like the thermic effect of food, which was very exaggerated here and given almost no context) is more likely to make people think that achieving a healthier weight is impossible so there’s no point in trying, and that’s a terrible message to send. It’s the same way when you hear people say “nutrition labels can be wrong by up to 10% so you can’t trust them!!” When the reality is ok if the label says it’s 100 calories but it’s actually 110… those secret 10 calories make such an insignificant difference to your intake on any one day. So if you’re paying attention and aiming to take in 2000 calories or whatever your goal is, yeah maybe you are taking in a bit more than you think. But if your goal is 2000 but you’re actually taking in 2200 because of that 10% rule (which is already at the very top end of that range) then you’re still doing better than if you think it’s pointless and unknowingly eat far more. Calories are NOT NEARLY as confusing as people want to make them out to be. Almost everyone has the ability to achieve a healthy weight. If it’s something you want to do, don’t let a video like this discourage you. Eat a balanced diet, mostly plants (they keep you full on very few calories and are super healthy!), don’t ever feel like you have to starve yourself, and be patient. You’ll get there. You got this.

Title is clickbait, although they don't actually express that it is a scam (which is good) because it isn't. Calories IN minus calories OUT determines weight gain or loss... nothing else. Yes, different people process different types of calories in different ways, and not every calorie is created equal, but this is a basic scientific fact for everyone, one that is unfortunately often overlooked en masse by your average person trying to lose a few lbs. The video is very informative, unfortunately I feel like it's playing into people's insecurities that tell them they can go do some crunches and "spot treat" their fat loss around their belly.

This isn't how that works. If you want to lose fat around your belly, you need to consume fewer calories than you burn in a day, consistently, for weeks or months. Counting calories (and averaging your total daily energy expenditure) can help you do this. You'll also find that your face, chest, arms and upper body will lose fat quicker than your belly, which is the first place excess fat goes, and the last place it comes off.

So while all points in this video are valid, please don't read the title and assume it's a wash and there is nothing to be done about it. I lost about 25 lbs over a few months by counting calories and exercising, and while I was restricting on my intake, I didn't really take it too seriously as to what I ate. You just start to make better decisions - do I want a muffin for lunch, or some chicken, rice and veggies? Of course, you want the muffin, but will it keep you going until dinner? Doubtful. Now that I am eating at maintenance (to not gain or lose weight) there is more leeway for desserts and junk foods etc.

This video is awful advice for anybody trying to lose weight and improve his health.
The ONLY way to lose weight is by eating fewer calories (energy) than your body expends. If a diet works, it does by helping you reduce your calories, hopefully far enough for the body to use more fat than it deposits. No magic involved.

Is energy in, energy out! And calories are the measure of energy.
And you can control what you measure!

The method I used to lose 25kg in 5 months: use the TDEE calculator to estimate your BMR. Get some fitness tracker to estimate the extra calories you spend (or just use the amazing Compendium of Physical Activities scientist build) or use the sedentary factor if you don't move much. Track every calorie, as good as you can with an app (there are many free apps around).
Eat what you like (use some common sense) BUT aim to have a calorie deficit of around 1% of your body weight using the "old" 3500kcal per pound of fat rule.
Get a scale and use it daily! Watch your body weight go down.
Maybe learn something about glycogen, sodium and transient weight if you are surprised by weight fluctuations and what to better understand them. You will even understand what a weight loss "plateau" is. After a couple of weeks, you will be able to predict how much weight you will lose in the next weeks if you keep doing the same.

If you can do a diet (all good diets are hard), you can do this one!

I used to count calories using MyFitnessPal to track what I was eating and calculate how many calories I needed, and I went from 200lbs to 160lbs over the course of 2 years (for context I am 5’5”). I stagnated for years though and couldn’t seem to lose more weight even though I kept exercising and cutting down on my calories. I was able to get down to 150lbs eating only 1200 calories a day and consistently going to the gym, but it took a lot of effort that was ultimately unsustainable. It wasn’t until about two years ago, when I switched to a plant based whole foods diet with very little processed food, that I found what really worked for my body. I stopped calorie counting altogether and have maintained my current weight at 130lbs for a full year, eating/living in a way that is healthy and sustainable for me. I don’t share this to say that what worked for me will work for you, but more to say that it’s important to really listen to your body and find what works for you. Though I don’t calorie count anymore, keeping track of what I ate when I started my weight loss journey definitely helped me to be more conscious of what I was putting in my body. At the end of the day, the only thing that matters is what works for you and your body.

I would like to point out that while people focus more on calories and what can we do to lose weight, having Firmicutes is not necessarily a bad thing.

1) several genera of Firmicutes including Bacillus, Clostridium, Enterococcus, Lactobacillus, and Ruminicoccus are actually seen as probiotics/ next-generation probiotics (beneficial bacteria). They can break down so-call non-digestible dietary fiber that we humans are not able to digest to produce some essential short-chain fatty acids that can provide energy to our intestinal tract and anti-inflammatory properties. limited inflammation by having more beneficial bacteria means you will have a healthier gut to absorption essential nutrients, which you will less likely experience obesity.

2) increasing the amount of Firmicutes to an unbalanced state will lead you to obesity while on the other hand increasing Bacteroidetes will lead to inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Therefore, it is not necessary which is better or worse but it's more important to have a balanced gut microbiome that will give you a healthy body.


Thank you for pointing out that the gut microbiome is actually important for our health and plays an important role in affecting our weight gain/loss!

All your science is right but the conclusions you draw have a clear bias. When it comes to weight loss, it's always simple thermodynamics. Calories in versus calories out isn't a rule of thumb, it's a scientific law. Just because person A tends to absorb more calories from certain foods than person B, they will still see results from cutting back the calories they ingest.

The calories you consume minus the calories your body burns equals the calories in mass that you gain or lose.

Calories don’t make you fat. Hormones make you fat. If you eat a food that spikes your insulin, or if your cortisol (stress) levels are up, if you aren’t sleeping enough (which regulates your hormones) etc, you will gain fat. If you eat things that don’t spike your insulin (fatty meats, butter, fiber heavy foods, etc), you won’t gain fat and instead use the energy for other functions such as heating your body or gaining muscle. This doesn’t bypass the law of thermodynamics as rather then telling your body to store the extra calories as fat, if you eat the right foods you’ll just use it for other metabolic functions. Your hormones tell your food energy where to go. It’s ridiculous to me that people think that an excess consumption of meat, vegetables, dairy, etc, is equally as fattening as an excess consumption of candy, cookies, pizza, processed food.

As a formal personal trainer, what I'd tell my clients was not to over think it. Eat a balanced and log and weigh it at first if possible to get an idea of what servings are supposed to look like according to the labels. If you want to lose fat, you should eat lower than your Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE) which is your Basil Metabolic Rate (BMR), or the calories you burn by existing, and the calories you burn with exercise. Same goes for if you want to gain weight by eating more. An online calculator gives you a rough estimate. If you're not seeing the results you want, toy with the numbers a bit and be sure to recalculate your TDEE every so often as that will change as your weight changes.

I think the discussion regarding calorie counting has been weirdly and misleadingly polarizing: it's either counting calories or something else.
But that's not the case at all. There are two significant things to consider:
1. Do you eat healthy foods
2. How much do you eat
And that's it. Calorie counting doesn't work in the sense that you could forget about food choices. The foundation of a good diet will always be healthy food options. However, after you get that sorted it comes down to portioning ie. calorie counting.

Another misconception is that you're supposed to blindly trust the numbers. The numbers you get from counting calories are most effectively viewed as a guideline and should always be viewed in the context of your personal results. The goal is to become aware of how much you can eat, to be able to compare different food options and make good decisions based on the experience you continually accrue.
This is, of course, something that's not dependent on counting anything. I for one have had a fairly steady diet for years and I don't need to count anything to know exactly when to eat more or less depending on my physical activity.
Basically: don't make things too hard for yourself.

Counting calories helps you link how your body feels, with the food you are consuming. You start to understand that 500 calories of pasta won't actually make you feel fuller longer, and that you'd do better to spread out those 500 calories across fruits, vegetables, proteins, and carbs. Once you start counting calories you'll realize that 400 calories of cereal isn't worth it. You'll realize that a 360 calorie soda doesn't provide enough enjoyment for what it costs your health. You'll learn to stop drinking your calories with high calorie fruit juices. You'll realize that 50 calories of candy is a great afternoon treat, but you don't need 300 calories of it to appreciate the enjoyment it brings. Counting calories helps you with portion size.

Counting calories should be encouraged as a way to intelligently monitor the food you eat and help you change your relationship with food, and the choices you make, and to better understand how you want to feel on a daily basis. Counting calories is both a short term solution to feeling better each day by eating healthier, and a long term solution to achieve better health in a sustainable way.

Anyone telling you to stop counting calories is more interested in telling you how easy and comfortable it is to change nothing about your life and your choices and get the results you want. Again, eating healthy and counting calories is simple to do, but it does take work and it can be difficult at times.

So what’s “the biggest lie about calorie counting”? Surely, calorie estimates on labels are just that: estimates. We all metabolize food differently. And yes, the thermic effect of breaking down protein is higher than that of carbs and fat.

However, I think it’s dishonest to not even mention in the video that weight loss and weight gain will always come down to calories in, calories out. It is a law of physics and there is no convincing me otherwise. You might not be eating the exact number of calories you think you are, but the bottom line is that weight change is a matter of energy balance.

This doesn’t imply that health is only about calories. But the hard truth is that if you want to lose weight, you must eat less calories than your body burns, consistently, over weeks. This is why i calorie count, it holds me accountable in showing me a rough estimate of how much I’m really eating every day.

A calorie is a calorie. Bodybuilders have been using calorie counting for decades to manipulate their weight VERY accurately. Differences between energy required to absorb different macronutrients are miniscule. If they weren't, people would pay more attention to it.

I've been studying this topic for a couple of months and what I've learned is this: a calorie is almost ultimately useless in defining weight gain/loss. Because biochemically your body doesn't deal with calories. It deals with carbs, proteins, fats, and nutrients. In biochemistry, you even don't find the word "calorie" because it is pointless and doesn't tell what your body stores and how it is used.
So "calories in > calories burned = weight gain" is a big misconception in all three parts of the equation.
It's all about carbs and fats (but mostly carbs). And as you pointed out - processed food makes it really easy for the body to process those extra carbs because your body doesn't need to burn more energy to extract glucose and nutrients from them. And "fast carbs" (processed foods, added sugars, etc) are the core of all the evil. Too much of those carbs will get you a fun ride on glucose levels roller coaster triggering high insulin resistance which in turns stores those carbs as "fat" and in the long run you gain chronic insulin resistance which in turn will make you eat more.

So in the end, weight gain/loss is defined by your hormones, and hormones are influenced by what type of food (read "carbs") you eat.
A calorie count may give you some info on the energy potential of the food but it won't tell you if you eat more of this food you'll gain weight.

As an example: it is really hard to gain weight from eating 200g of beef alone but it becomes easy if you replace it with calorie equivalent cookies. Because you won't gain any carbs from beef, only proteins and fats and proteins are not used for energy. Even more - it'll take a lot of time and energy for your body to process that beef. While cookies are loaded with fast carbs and most of those carbs are come from sugars.

Here are my thoughts based on what I have learned and viewing your video.  First, counting calories will assure you that you do not get into a ‘weigh loss plateau.’  For 2 months I was frustrated after not being able to lose fat 6 months into my journey.  A dietitian evaluated my meal plan and said “you are not eating enough” which dumbfounded my logic.  So I increased my calorie intake by 400 more calories and the fat loss steadily picked up again for another 8 months and I plateau-d again but I ended up at my target weight loss of 100 lbs.  At this point I increased my caloric intake by another 400 - 700 calories to maintain my weight of 185 and have done so for the past 8 months. Second, in order to make calories count, you need to eat the right foods, especially since it does not take that many calories to maintain weight let alone lose weight.  Third, the key to weight loss and health management is you managing your hormones to ideal targets - your body is very efficient and storing or burning fat - you just need to turn on the burning fat path through managing your hormones (melatonin, IhG, insulin, leptin, ghrelin, glucagon, cortisol, etc.).  There is no “perfect” diet or calorie number to managing your calories, but counting calories for me has allowed me to learn more about foods available so that when I do eat I maximize my nutritional benefit per calorie and helps me in assuring my daily macros are balanced out.

There's no universal answer to weight management. Each person is vastly different than the next. I don't have any food allergies, but if I eat any amount of rice or dairy I'll immediately gain 5lbs. I'm a 6ft tall built male who exercises 5hrs daily and I eat less than 1200 calories a day (all home prepared, no fast food, microwave, or junk) and only a single meal and I don't drop below 185lbs. I lose weight when I eat McDonalds which is once every 3-4 months (probably because my diet is otherwise lacking fatty foods and other things found in fast foods). I suspect that sodium plays a big role on weight gain as well, but haven't properly tested it on myself yet.
I believe that everyone is being told to eat way too much, too often, at the wrong times, and that they eat foods that their body immediately turns into weight gain even if it doesn't have the same affect on other people. I believe that adult bodies have grown so efficient at energy management that they hardly need to eat at all. I also believe that weight gain is a display of weakness and stupidity and that its something people should feel inclined to manage. Obviously people go through at least one fat phase in their life, but they should never get stuck in that phase. I peaked at 210lbs.
But ya anyway, your diet isn't something you can learn from other people and its not as simple as avoiding something like calories or fat. You have to learn how your body reacts to different foods and pay attention to know when something is causing weight gain or weight loss. You might be able to double your calorie intake and lose weight if your weight is caused by one or two food items that your body doesn't process normally. I could gain 50lbs in two months with just milk and rice. I'll gain 5lbs for days if my parents make rice one time when I visit (they don't have to know that). I cut dairy out for four years and more aspects of my health improved vastly as well. Sucks because dairy is literally my favorite thing. At least I don't gain weight from drinking beer or cocktails.

Counting calories is clearly a rough estimate of how many calories actually get used by your body. Even subtle differences in amount of ingredients used in any particular “batch” of food varies a bit. The point is to get a rough idea of just how many calories you’re eating. This is critical information if you want or need to lose weight. No matter which diet you are following, if you eat more calories than you need, you will gain weight, if you eat just enough, you will stay the same weight, and if you eat less, you will lose weight. That’s a constant that never changes in weight loss. Obviously there’s TONS more to it than just that. Sure, you could technically eat 1800 calories of candy every day and as long as you burned more than that in a day, you’d lose weight, but for many reasons, including everything outlined in this video, that isn’t really the best idea. You’ll be hungry all the time, you’ll probably lose just as much muscle as fat when you do lose weight, your blood sugar will spike stressing your pancreas, your micro biome will change, and you won’t get any of the nutrients your body needs not to mention mental fog, mood swings etc. You can also be sure your body will digest and absorb close to 100% of the calories in the candy. But you will lose weight, there’s no question about that. So use calorie counting for what it’s meant to do, help you lose weight. Same goes for the other extreme. If you eat 2500 calories of fruit and veggies, you’d be extremely full, but you’d also gain weight if you didn’t burn that many calories for the day. You need to eat healthy foods as much as possible, and calorie counting helps you figure out what you can and can’t eat on your journey. Can you afford to eat a little cake? You want to consume more protein, will that push you over your calorie budget? If so, will you have to find more protein dense foods? Basically, choose a diet that’s specific to your needs whether it’s blood sugar control, overall health, lowering cholesterol levels, lowering blood pressure, living longer, building muscle etc. and then if losing weight is also one of your goals, you can use calorie counting to help you budget your food in a way that will allow you to lose weight.

Calorie counting is a useful and valuable form of biofeedback that is helpful for adjusting eating habits. If you confine yourself to a calorie budget, you will start valuing food that provides greater satisfaction and fullness. This will drive you towards more nutrient dense foods and away from "empty" calorie foods. Yea, its not perfect, but most biofeedback is just about giving your brain a way to check itself rather than stewing in complacency (why change something if you don't know its broken?).

Just like weighing yourself is a necessary biofeedback to weight-loss, calorie counting should not be done too rigidly. Between unknown variance in how much calories you actually absorb, actually burn, and are actually in the food you are eating, there is no reason to stress about being exact (you want to be pretty well ballparked and close to your budget level, but it doesn't have to be exact every single day). Similarly you should really only weigh yourself once a week (consistently on about the same day and time) because your weight fluctuates throughout the day and throughout the week and the constant changes might mess with your head negatively, while the habitual measurement keeps you honest.

Oh, and people are obsessed with fat and muscle because we are essentially fat, muscles and bones, and you don't get biofeedback on how your bones are doing when you casually glance at yourself a thousand times a day and they don't really change that much on a day to day basis.

I went for my yearly physical a few years ago and the scale said 302lb.  It was shocking.  I was never that heavy.  So I changed what I eat and how much I eat.  I stopped eating 3 big slices of pizza and started eating salads. You get the idea.  But, I also limited myself to 1500 calories a day.  Not pizza calories, but better calories.  Beer didn't count, and I never let myself go hungry because it would push me over my daily quota.  I dropped down to 202 in about 18 months, and I've been there ever since.  I stick to the same diet because I know that if I go back to my old ways, I'll go back to my old size.  I feel better about myself because I'm not 302, but also because I've managed to lose 100lbs and keep it off.  So, for me, counting calories worked, and continues to work.  But it wasn't just 1500 of the same calories as I used to eat.  It was 1500 calories of new foods with lower fat and higher protein.
